lib/apache.message:
This exapnds to

 ProxyPass "/placement" "unix:/var/run/uwsgi/placement-api.socket|uwsgi://uwsgi-uds-placement-api" retry=0 

on the host.  So per discussion in #openstack-qa, https://httpd.apache.org/docs/trunk/mod/mod_proxy.html#proxypass says

"If the first argument ends with a trailing /, the second argument should also end with a trailing /, and vice versa. Otherwise, the resulting requests to the backend may miss some needed slashes and do not deliver the expected results."

So it seems we either need to do this, and should probably strip any trailing slashes from ${url} for good measure -- or do the opposite; keep the trailing ${name}/ and ensure ${url} has a trailing slash.

Not sure which is better?

We can add a redirect from /placement to /placement/ but I'm not sure about that being a breaking change. The API is defined starting with /, /placement is just a prefix to that so the contract is still valid.
Agreed with Gibi, the endpoint should not have a trailed slash for getting the WSGI app.

I think we need to use the '/placement' variant to allow GET http://<ip>/placement to be routed to the placement app. As far as I see if we use '/placement/' variant then GET <ip>/placement is not routed and that would be a breaking API change.
It seems that the trailing / case breaks keystone in devstack https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/36e95d6ba37f4c58891ce6d254518a1f/log/job-output.txt#15671

Does somebody want to propose a final change?  Personally I think the / variant because it seems sane and matches [1].  IMO we should either reject a ${url} without a trailing slash or just add one if missing.

[1] https://uwsgi-docs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Apache.html#mod-proxy-uwsgi

Hm, now I looked at it from the perspective how nova works. Right now both 
http://<ip>/compute and http://<>/compute/ is routed to the app and result in the version document returned. 

Also I've checked and placement before the Apache change worked the same way as nova. 

I withdraw my argument about API correctness as you are right Radoslaw, we are defining our API as simply starting with '/' so based on that 'any-prefix/' is correct but 'any-prefix' is not correct.  Still I'm wondering if want to start rejecting 'any-prefix' now, and for placement only.

To flesh this out, I've tried with both

 ProxyPass "/placement/" "unix:/var/run/uwsgi/placement-api.socket|uwsgi://uwsgi-uds-placement-api/" retry=0 

and

 ProxyPass "/placement" "unix:/var/run/uwsgi/placement-api.socket|uwsgi://uwsgi-uds-placement-api" retry=0 

and both appear to work with the latest Apache (104.130.219.63 is the held node where I was playing with this; feel free to poke).

I'm not sure which is the better format to enforce here?  Flip a coin?

I proposed https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/devstack/+/811389 on Xena that does the / appending.  Not attached to it so please upload over it, etc. as required.  I figure we can cherry-pick it to master

helm-toolkit/templates/snippets/_kuberne.message: I'm not sure if this is the right place in the values tree to put the configuration, if anyone knows a better place just let me know.
do we need the default: and bar: keys. I don't see the need to differentiate them as they just all get consolidated to labels

The difference between them is that default (maybe I should instead name it something like common?) get applied to all resources that use this snippet while bar only to the bar component.

So practically you could for example allow Istio sidecar ingestion on only api pods (and not jobs). While adding the Istio app label to all resources.
Ah, I understand now. Would this make sense to use the top level key labels: in the Values.yaml?

In some way, I think it makes more sense than using pod.labels, however right now the labels section is used to define node selector labels so it could become confusing once we start combining the two.

tests/unit/test_timer_driver.py.message: Does it make sense to create a test-job1 and test-job2 for the respective tenants and projects then also check that the jobs don't leak across? I think this is sufficient to prevent regressions like the current bug we are fixing, but wonder if this would be good belts and suspenders against potential other issues.

We could, but I think/hope that we have "pipeline runs the right job" covered elsewhere.  I tried to give Zuul as much rope as possible here to get it wrong (by ensuring that we don't do something based on the job before we get to the point where an incorrect change object would cause an error).  If we added other jobs, we'd have to at least run 12 jobs in the test (instead of 4) in order to allow for all error possibilities.

Instead of removing it, let's just turn it off when we're working with sensitive data. In this file, we should `set +x` after line 39, and the turn it back on with `set -x` after line 44

I'll fix that.
s/costumer/customer :)
I'll fix that.

IIUC the rescue spec, the rescue ramdisk will be booted on rescue network, but after startup will switch back to tenant network, could you clarify what is the "problem in production environment" might be?

Hi Vladyslav,

I think there would be no problem if a bare metal server supported only traditional NIC which only support untag ethernet packet.
But I believe that it would not so simple in case that NIC supported PCI virtual function such as Emulex CNA card.
In order to create NIC and iSCSI on one physical ethernet port of the NIC, the physical siwtch port has to be trunk mode.
But PXE client fw code in NIC doesn't understand VLAN, but PXE client code in UEFI understand VLAN.
It's really complected situation.

Best regards,
Naohiro

One correction:-)

Wrong: In order to create NIC and iSCSI on one physical ethernet port of the NIC, the physical siwtch port has to be trunk mode.

Correct: In order to create NIC and iSCSI on one physical ethernet port of the *CNA*, the physical siwtch port has to be trunk mode.

Best regards,
Naohiro

Hi Naohiro, thanks for the reply. I see what you mean, but the current implementation of multitenancy is based on using vlans, so interfaces assigned to tenant networks can be easily switched to rescue network by just changing vlan. Am I missing something? Anyway, I think supporting OOB rescue is a good thing :)

Vladyslav,

Thanks for the review!

One example I can think of is like this:

Assume a bare metal server has 4 NICs.
2 NICs are used to boot OS via iSCSI from Cinder volume for multipath or teaming, and the other 2 NICs are used tenant network for bonding or teaming, then somehow the OS turned not to respond.

In order to investigate if this problem is either iscsi path or tenant network path by booting rescue image from rescue network, this is impossible. Because there are only 4 NICs.
There is no NIC to be assigned to rescue network.

Did I answer your question?

Best regards,
Naohiro.
This has to be updated to the ``irmc`` hardware type.
in-band?

I would document this more as a command with options rather than multiple commands.
e.g.


The **show-certs.sh** command has the following syntax:

    sudo show-certs.sh [-k] [-e <number-of-days>] [-h]


where:

    By default, with no options, displays the platform-managed system certificates,
    highlighting (in red) certificates requiring manual renewal and certificates
    within 90 days of expiry.

    -k   displays certificates found in any Kubernetes SECRETS; 
         this may include platform certificates and end-users' certificates.
     
    -e <number-of-days>
         Changes to highlight (in red) certificates within <number-of-days> of expiry.

    -h   Displays help.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
yeah but how does *that* happen - when would an unsharded db replica decide to create a new own_shard_range

in all my testing with rebalanced parts and handoffs the unsharded fresh db always picks up shard ranges from it's peers during replication

sigh, I've been playing with a probe test that is trying it hit different scenarios where we "might" pull a default own shard range:

1. Hand off node gets a new container DB on PUT. Replication gets objs count, sharder triggers a defailt own_shard_range which has a newer TS. 
  - Turns out this doesn't happen because replication gets all shard ranges including the own_shard_range of the other root primariys.

2, Rebalance happens, there is a new primary, it gets a PUT and enough objects before the it replicates with any others.
  - This might cause a shard candidate but won't trigger a own_shard_range generation unless sharding is enabled.. in which case it'll get a new epoch anyway, not None. 

Problem is, we don't tend to write back a default own_shard_range in many places. except if it's enabling sharding. We don't even write back an own_shard_range much (in the root that is). And we can't get sharder to trigger anywhere it does without getting object counts big enough, and if it does then it'll get them from either the other primaries or will shard with a new epoch.

It could be in s-m-s-r enable code, but likewise to get there it needs to first be a sharding candidate.

I'm going to keep probing. This time will look closer at where we are using the sharding state checking and more own_shard_range paths. Then instead of trying to find a situation where a "new" container could infect existing, see if I can find a place or way we can fail to return an own_shard_range so it'll be defaulted.

Sorry for the brain dump status update, just trying to find the edge case.

We're dealing with own_shard_ranges. When we see these reset roots they're unsharded because it's missing the epoch in the own_shard_range, they still have all the shards. Because as you said they always share all shards. 

But after thinking some more, it could also possibly happen in s-m-s-r, maybe if someone tries to run it on a handoff that isn't actaully sharded. ie does the recon sharding candidates strickly only dump primaries or _anything_ (ie handoffs). 

I'll have a play.

swift/container/backend.py.message:
this all sounds reasonable; but it's not obviously a problem

If the issue is own_shard_range *only* why are we way down here in merge_shards which effects *everything*?

Is there a more obvious/direct/targeted way to prevent this for just own_shard_range?  Is it ever reasonable to allow any shard_range (not just osr) to merge without an epoch (obviously we have lots of tests doing exactly that; but we can fix the tests)

I've got this nagging feeling like we should also have a

 if existing['epoch'] and shard_data['epoch'] and \
         existing['epoch'] != shard_data['epoch']:
     return shard_data['epoch'] > existing['epoch']
I'm trying to remember why I felt the need to add this here, and whether it makes sense for us to reset it with any of the epoch differences, too.

yeah, it's a good quetion. I guess if shard data we'd return the new data, but do we need to update the root to report data on that or cuold we assume that the other node we recieved it from already did that. I guess we do it here for timestamp so doesn't hurt to do it for epoch too.. worst case we report stats again.

test/probe/test_sharder.py.message: maybe we could break this test up so we can see each scenario indepdently - obviously we want to keep the other stuff working; but i'm most interested in just the *difference* of how swift behaves with *this* change and without

test/unit/container/test_backend.py.message: why would we have a non-default osr without an epoch!?  Is this reasonable?  Isn't this the problem?

no_deafult=True, just means to either return an existing OSR or a None, don't always return an osr (being exisiting or a new one (default)).

So the own SR we put in has no epoch, we're pulling it out again and making sure it's still the same.

As the to question, why would we have a non-default without an epoch. An epoch is added when it's time to shard. So shards will have an osr without an epoch. But when a shard shards an epoch will be added. This allows us to know when it was marked as sharding. If the epch doesn't match the db epoch (in the filename) then it's also considered unsharded. (https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/master/swift/container/backend.py#L408)
So we can't just always set an epoch either 😞

test/unit/container/test_sharder.py.message: this was a huge smell to me - do we want to allow an osr w/o and epoch to merge ever?!

yeah, most shard osr's wont have an epoch unless they're sharding, then they'll shard and delete themselves.

I know.. the whole epoch thing can get a little confusing.

swift/container/replicator.py.message: Is the logging going to be a little noisy now that we've dropped this? Or is there really *no reason* we should ever be merging an own-shard-range with None epoch?

I worry about shards if we remove this. By default a shard will have an OSR but no epoch because it isn't sharding. I guess we could argue that there shouldn't be shards to share, but sharing their epochs if both the same seems to make sense, so they agree on state, right?

When turning on something like shrinking and we tell one acceptor that it's range has increased we expect it to replicate to the other primarys for the shard, and without this check this might break it. Oh, but this may be ok, in the new world order of shrinking we plan to be root driven. Update the acceptor in the root and it'll pull down and merge roots view.. so shrinking "should" be ok.

Fact that shards don't have epoch if why I went to the effort of this check.
Yeah, the previous patch was doing the DB call too much.
was it, I thought it would only call it once on each side of replication (ie on the sender and the rpc. Though I think I need to reload it all after my vacation 😊

as Matt pointed out, this will be triggered by shards (which have no epoch):

with this patch I see these logs on a healthy system:

  Sep 27 09:48:43 saio container-6031[22255]: Ignoring remote osr w/o epoch: {u'object_count': 4, u'lower': u'obj-0002', u'name': u'.shards_AUTH_test/container-974d0ea4-189f-443f-89f8-5696c7dbf12f-91de5461f984a9ec07018

can we add `broker.db_epoch is not None` to the condition to narrow this warning to shard[ing|ed] db's without needing to query own_sr? or just query own_sr for epoch is not None (which might be more explicit).

boo; ok something has to change then - nice find.

But, I'm not so sure why a shard shouldn't have an epoch - someone must have decided to create it, wouldn't they want to jot down WHEN the came to this conclusion? (seems like an epoch could be useful when resolving split paths)
Yup, this should be warning. I'll update this in the parent patch while this discussion here continues.
+1 return a new list, no side-effects

manilaclient/v2/quota_classes.py.message:
Since these parameters are available only from 2.40, the convention is to override this for that microversion and beyond, so that the version picker does the right thing. Right now, this method is allowed for all microversions > 2.6 and < 2.53.. This isn't what you want... 


   @api_versions.wraps("2.7", "2.39")  # noqa
    def update(self, class_name, shares=None, gigabytes=None,  # noqa
               snapshots=None, snapshot_gigabytes=None, share_networks=None):
        return self._do_update(
            class_name, shares=shares, gigabytes=gigabytes,
            snapshots=snapshots, snapshot_gigabytes=snapshot_gigabytes,
            share_networks=share_networks, share_groups=share_groups,
            share_group_snapshots=share_group_snapshots,
            resource_path=RESOURCE_PATH)

  @api_versions.wraps("2.40", "2.52")  # noqa
    def update(self, class_name, shares=None, gigabytes=None,  # noqa
               snapshots=None, snapshot_gigabytes=None, share_networks=None,
               share_groups=None, share_group_snapshots=None):
        return self._do_update(
            class_name, shares=shares, gigabytes=gigabytes,
            snapshots=snapshots, snapshot_gigabytes=snapshot_gigabytes,
            share_networks=share_networks, share_groups=share_groups,
            share_group_snapshots=share_group_snapshots,
            resource_path=RESOURCE_PATH)

> micversion in 2.7-->2.39, function self._do_updata() remove share_groups and share_group_snapshots parameter.

Ah yes, thanks haixin.

micversion in 2.7-->2.39, function self._do_updata() remove share_groups and share_group_snapshots parameter.

               snapshots=None, snapshot_gigabytes=None, share_networks=None):
        return self._do_update(
            class_name, shares=shares, gigabytes=gigabytes,
            snapshots=snapshots, snapshot_gigabytes=snapshot_gigabytes,
            share_networks=share_networks,

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message:
with this change, doesnt this mean if someone does not pass g_audit to this manifest, there will no longer be this value.
Do we want the default to be audit=1, so the code acts with the same default as before this change?

We do not want audit=1 as default as done in previous impl. We want to give the customer the choice to set it and this is why we are introducing the service parameter. We are avoiding also the audit backlog limit exceeded, because if auditd daemon does not start in a reasonable amount of time the audit queue gets exceeded. By default now audit=0, as it has always been.

ic, "g_audit= ' '" should be equivalent of "audit=0'; however, would this then mean that if grub was already set with 'audit=1' the platform::compute::grub::update will be able to remove the older keys from grub?

The fresh install will set the service param value and implicitly the grub param in the kernel as audit=0. Using service param modify command the grub param can be set to 1 and then set back to 0. So the older audit grub key values will be overwritten rather than removed.
Please confirm on an upgrade from stx5.0/21.05; where the default is 'audit=0' ; i.e. will that kernel grub parameter be replaced on the upgrade?

The service parameter does not exist in stx5.0/21.05. According to David unless there is an issue with add/delete service parameter which I tested successfully, it should not be any impact to upgrade.

In the spirit of this PR, the 'type' key should precede the 'default' key. See also:

use-internal-endpoints:
restrict-ceph-pools:

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/conductor/ma.message:
Can you remind me of the need for the interface class to be 'none'?  I would think in most cases of a card replacement, it's because it's being used for something and has gone bad.  Which is fine - there's going to be some documentation required for this procedure, including the need to reconfig a deleted/re-added card.

I'm thinking of the case of replacing a nic being used for SR-IOV.  Let's say the original one in the DB is configured for 64 VFs.  It gets replaced by a different vendor/device_id that has a max of 32 VFs.  Since it is not removed from the DB because the class is pci-sriov, won't this cause issues when puppet tries to enable 64 VFs against that PCI addr?
Alarm for ports implemented to make the operator aware that he needs to remove previous configuration if he executed the HW exchange first

I wonder if it would make sense to raise an alarm if there is a discrepancy between the sysinv report + db.  For example in the case that a device dies and is not reported by Linux anymore.  This would allow the operator to (hopefully) see the problem sooner, and we can add some sort of link from the alarm ID and the recommended steps for resolution (replacing the card and removing config from dependent interfaces).

The idea behind this is to prevent database removal without the dependant interface configuration be removed first.

Just to remember the sequence:
1) operator detects that the NIC needs to be replaced, at this point Linux might not be reporting the interface anymore. For example, this interface is an SRIOV-PF with some SRIOV-VF on top of it.
2) If we erase the entry for the SRIOV-PF, the database will still have the VFs pointing to the deleted port. Depending on the configuration he might not be able to lock the controller
3) If we keep it while configured, the operator will be able to lock the controller and start the config removal (as will be explained on the doc) before powering down the controller for replacement.

If the config was not changed after replacement (by not following the documentation), the operator still can remove the configuration and force a sysinv-agent restart before unlocking or, do an extra cycle of lock/unlock (if the new card is a superset of the old one). 
But in this case, if the new card does not support the old config (32 VFs instead of 64 VFs, as in your example) we might get some issues, mostly because the documentation wasn't followed.
So in this case we've got a port in the DB that wasn't inventoried by the sysinv agent.  Do we need a LOG here similar to 2140 if it has a class/used-by?
Done
After deletion, the new port will show up at the next iport_update_by_ihost() ... do you know the time period here where we will appear to have a missing port/interface?

For AIO-SX the audit in sysinv-agent does not continuously send the report for the conductor
as self._report_to_conductor() returns false in SX (the other setups generate at 5 minutes interval). In SX usually on sysinv-agent start or after configuration the data is updated.
The only situation we will not report on the CLI an entry (old or new) is if the unconfigured port is no longer reported by Linux.
This will happen in 2 situations:
1) prior replacement, if the defect card is no longer reported by Linux and has no configuration (which IMO is OK as the operator is preparing for replacement)
2) after power up, if the slot remains empty or it really does not show up to Linux

"The search also detects for FEC devices no longer reported on a"

It looks like this function is only doing ports+interfaces, and there's a separate function for the FEC devices
Done
This is not the same of lines 2255-2257.
Done
Couldn't be "unreported" here, too?
Done
Insert space.
Done
Same as in line 2179.
Done
Isn't better to name it 'has_removed' since unreported is included together with replaced?
Done
I don't think the VF's PCI device ID needs to be included here, since it is not stored at database (notice the N3000_DEVICES list does not include the N3000_FEC_VF_DEVICE, too), is it?
Done

I suggest you to run a B&R procedure to verify this won't conflict with the existing logic to clean up (or not, which is more important) stale entries. Notice your new method _process_fec_device_replacement() is called from pci_device_update_by_host() *before* the existing call to cleanup_stale_n3000_devices().
I introduced in https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/stx-puppet/+/797330 an additional logic to prevent restored entries to be cleaned while the AIO/worker manifest did not complete the device configuration. I'm wondering if this new logic wouldn't get rid with that entry by mistake.

This new code only runs if the system is AIO-SX
I'm keeping the cleanup_stale_n3000_devices method to be run for the other setups.
Since we do not accept non-reseted N3000 devices on the database, we still might need to
clear stale entries from an upgrade.
Updating the condition to handle only non-AIO-SX setups and updated the comment

From both second thought and our off-line talk: since that with both https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/config/+/796849 (no more DB entries for unreset device) and https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/stx-puppet/+/797330 (no wait for configuration to reset) already merged the occurrence of stale entries might not happen anymore, this logic could actually *replace* that cleanup procedure. Please consider removing that logic from conductor and agents (not from RPC API since it could be an issue in multinode upgrades).

In this case, I'm adding Teresa Ho to reviewers since she's introduced the cleanup procedure.
Ack

In this case it will actually be a port existing in the DB that is _not_ being reported by the sysinv agent anymore.  Also, I think the upper interfaces should be removed before the associated interface class is reset.

The reason text does note this, so I think we can remove the first sentence from the proposed repair action:

Maybe:

Lock the host, remove any associated 'used by i/f' interfaces, set the associated interface class to 'none', and unlock the host.
Done
nit: "Failed to"
Done

This clear operation appears to result in a GET call into fm-api for each ethernet port ... consider more efficient method to cache a list of related alarms prior to the port loop.
This is currently for SX only so scope is currently limited.
Collecting once port alarms from FM and processing against the local data
looks like it can break from this double loop once these variables are set
the loop is needed to generate the pci_addr_dict data structure, to be used to compare against the DB
This param has been removed

python-k8sapp-nginx-ingress-controller/k.message:
I think some comments would be helpful to understand the manipulation of user-overrides.

ReapplyAdmissionWebhook - used as a flag to short-circuit webhook creation logic during post-backup and post-restore.  This name has no previous significance; it is introduced here.

DISABLE_ADMISSION_WEBHOOK_OVERRIDE_CREATION - disabling the webhook creation in order to prevent it found being recreated too early.  Explicitly set the chart value "enabled" to false.  Compare CREATE_ADMISSION_WEBHOOK_OVERRIDE + ': enabled".

BACKUP_ADMISSION_WEBHOOK_OVERRIDE - swapping out the enabled webhook with a "backup" name in order to simply recreating it.  The user overrides are presented as a string, so CREATE_ADMISSION_WEBHOOK_OVERRIDE is replaced with BACKUP_ADMISSION_WEBHOOK_OVERRIDE in pre-backup, and restored in post backup and post restore operations.

The method name does not need to be so long does it?

_get_webhook_configuration()
I was trying to be explicit here about what the method was doing (which is a good practice) but that doesn't really seem necessary here given the class and application we are in. Renamed.

I understand that you may have had to fix extra things because of recent zuul gate job adjustments.  If there are any changes that are unnecessary, for example if zuul didn't complain, then I would not want to see them in this commit.

This function for example seems to have no changes except for adding forms of whitespace, and you made the change before zuul gave a -1
This was just me autoformatting this part alongside my changes. I'll revert it.
nit: 'It is necessary to disable the webhook creation in order to prevent that it finds it being created too early'
I see that you check for None in line 200. I would do that first than checking len()
What I mean is that there are no None checks here, only list size checks given that `kube_get_validating_webhook_configurations_by_selector` should return a list, be it empty or filled.
line 200 is a none check, line 196 is a len check. Doesn't it make more sense to have the None check first ?
It isn't a None check, but an empty list check.

tacker/objects/vnf_lcm_subscriptions.py.message: I think it's too nested and hard to imagine the final result of a SQL query string created here, It might be better to refactor it and flatten it. Also, + operator is too slow, how about `join`ing all parts of a SQL query at the end instead of concating a part of a query for each step?

I think it`s hard to imagine the final result of a SQL query string created here too. Before running the old code, I spent a long time without figuring out what SQL query string it will generate. But from the perspective of respecting the old code, I did not rewrite this code, but only corrected the errors. And I agree that `join`ing all parts of a SQL query at the end is better than + operator for each step. I will adopt your suggestion in patch 2.
I don't understand why you assign `sql_lst`, stands for a list of SQL? Is there any reason to have a list at once and join later which looks something make it complex a bit?

Hiromu Asahina san commented in the previous code. The efficiency is too slow if you directly use the `+` operator, so the `join` method improves the efficiency. The detailed content can be viewed in this comment's point 3.
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tacker/+/797804/1..5#message-a45b53a3ec4c1658a13bdf07097cce642232b643

ovn_bgp_agent/drivers/openstack/ovn_evpn.message: veth_name and veth_peer, maybe we should call it veth_vrf, veth_ovs respectively ? Idk, at least for me it makes it easier to know which end is plugged where
Why we always want to return None here, if it's always None maybe we shouldn't even return it ?

Would be good to docstring this method given the # of values being returned here.

I would also recommend using a namedtuple as a return value here, for example:

# Define this at the beggning of the this file
EVPN_INFO = collections.namedtuple('EVPNInfo', ['vrf_name', 'lo_name', 'bridge_name', 'vxlan_name', 'veth_vrf', 'veth_ovs'])

# Return this in this method
return EVPN_INFO(vrf_name, lo_name, bridge_name, vxlan_name, veth_name, veth_peer)

# On the receive end we have it as
evpn_info = self.__ensure_evpn_devices(...)
evpn_info.vrf_name
this is because in the vlan_tag case we will return vlan there, and None in the veth related ones. And in the non-vlan_tag case the opossite (line 585 vs 594)

nit: Don't need to change if there's no need to send another patch-set

 veth_key = 'vlan' if vlan_tag else 'veth_vrf'
 for ip in ips:
     linux_net.del_ip_nei(ip, cr_lrp_info['mac'],
                          cr_lrp_info[veth_key])

doc/source/dist_cloud/kubernetes/install.message: Shouldn't it be "Dedicated Storage" which can be either dedicated storage nodes or Netapp?

Yeah I would have this as two separate bullets ... typically the way we describe these configs

- Standard with dedicated internal Storage Nodes and 1 or more Worker Nodes
- Standard with dedicated external Netapp Storage backend and 1 or more Worker Nodes
Do we support and test this for systemController ?
Waiting for confirmation to delete this bullet.
Hi Elisamara.  Please keep this bullet.  I have reviewed today with the engineers responsible for this configuration and they agree that a Standard configuration with controller storage is supported.

I am not aware that this line needed to change.  It seems to me that the reason it is changed is because the text from an older version of this file was used as example in the bug description.  The old text was copied on top of the changes made to this file since the bug was created.  It reverts work that Juanita had submitted in a recent commit 996f391e (I948fc1189e6777a2246957e4a8df164ad00da8a6).

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/commo.message: I know this is a copy of other code, but are we sure the active version will always be the first in this list?
The kube_cmd_versions table will always have 1 entry. We use this table when upgrading k8s and it will always have the active kubelet and kubeadm versions that are running on the system.

Don't see an "active" field in that table but if there will be more than one entry then this may not be a reliable way to get the active kubelet version. Perhaps the following command would work:

kubectl version --client=true --short=true | awk '{print $3}'

The same code to get the kubernetes_version in the DB in bootstrap playbook is ok as at bootstrap there is at most 1 version. The tasks used in the backup playbook, which can executed any time after the system is fully deployed, may not be reliable also.

doc/source/user/adding-and-removing-host.message: This works, but the actual option is named --all-projects

gbpservice/neutron/services/apic_aim/l3_.message: You can probably remove this (see below).

You actually can reference the _core_plugin member to get networks:
https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/branch/master/neutron/db/l3_db.py#L139-L141

From that, you can do something like:

self._core_plugin._get_network(context, current_gw_info['network_id'])

While reviewing this patch, I was looking at this, and wasn't sure that we're covering the case where the router gateway is updated. In other words, a single REST call is made that removes the old gateway and sets a new one. In this case, both original_gw_info and current_gw_info would not be None or ATTR_NOT_SPECIFIED, but would be different from each other.

I would instead change this to get the network, as per the change suggested above:

network_db = self._core_plugin._get_network(context, current_gw_info['network_id'])

I believe that this returns the subnet ORM objects when you reference network.subnets, which  means you should be able to just use this to iterate over them in line to 274.
I think you need to see if a subnet exists here, and below (e.g. "if sub and subn['network_id']....")

zuul/model.py.message: Are we sure we want to log data here?  It could be quite large if the job returns a lot of data.  It could also be sensitive.
Right, maybe data is a little too much here. I thought it only contains a small dict, but in case of a successful build, it might be a lot larger. I'll remove it.

zuul/scheduler.py.message: It's worth thinking about whether we still need this, or if we can rely on the scheduler having already actually canceled the build.  This was added in I14a3ad24feffcee5e999bef30d7c774e4be4fb92 but with the queue in ZK now, we may not need it any more.
Thanks for the hint, I will try that out.

Are we talking about an active canceling here? So the scheduler explicitly cancels the builds, but that wasn't working for paused builds correctly until https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/667072?

If so, I think this should work fine with the builds in ZooKeeper, as the scheduler is either canceling (and deleting) those builds directly in case they are not locked or schedules a cancel event which should be picked up by the executor independently of the job being paused or not. This snipped here might also be relevant for this (resuming a paused job before it is aborted): https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul/src/branch/master/zuul/executor/server.py#L977
It looks like this is the only place where build_request_ref is used.  The path is predictable, so maybe instead of passing it through ZK on the result object, we can just re-generate it here?

That would work, but we would need to store the zone on the result event instead to generate the correct path. I thought I had a comment about that somewhere in this change, but it looks like I've removed that already.
It's indexed by job name, so computationally this is technically a little faster, but not enough to matter.  I'm ambivalent about it.
Might even simplify this by looking up the build by uuid and not job name?

I think not; we should remove builds from the pipelines when we abort them, and we don't keep old buildsets around.  And when we put them in ZK, I'm also expecting to delete them at that point.

We should probably just adjust the sql report methods so they don't take build objects but instead just take all these parameters, then just make sure they're all included in the completed event.  Then I think this method could be streamlined a bit.  That will also make things easier for the pipeline state in zk series.

This get method only looks at current builds in a pipeline. Below we hint that we could hit this block because the build is outdated. Are we able to lookup outdated builds and handle them without a fake Build object? If so that might be a bit cleaner?
Agree: not wrong but not necessary.
I think this will always be True because we don't set build.retry to True above.

This is (kind of) related to the TODO block at line 2005. Not sure if that is a problem or not, but I wanted to write it down somewhere. I think it shouldn't matter too much as the result is outdated anyways, so we might just remove the TODO and the (not build.retry) expression.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Could you confirm this somehow? Or at least let me know how I can test it locally?

On my bifrost VM copying a 700 MiB image (non-sparse) takes 0.4 seconds of real time. It's probably not an issue.
